column2: shannonbz, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am 42 and have two kids.  I was having very heavy and long periods.  I did have polyps removed and mirena was recommended by Obgyn.  The 1st period was about the same then the 2nd was shorter and lighter only about 4 days.  This has continued hoping they will stop all the way but happy with this result.  I feel so much better.  No side effects at all for me.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Love it. Just had my second one inserted a week ago. Had cramping for a few hours and no spotting at all. wish is wasnt so expensive though. R2 200 South African Rands.

column2: barrones, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I decided to get Mirena after the birth of my son in November 2012. It did not hurt to get placed,but the was a long month and half of bleeding(heavy to light). Then I started to notice that my hair started coming out when I combed it. 71/2 months later the only side effects is that my hair is still coming out.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was had the mirena placed after being on the pill for about a year and a half and I loved it! No periods, no acne and no headaches/migraines... Unfortunately the only side effect I had was hair loss. In 7 months I had lost half of my hair, it didn't want to curl any longer and the volume was gone. Had it taken out and it's been 2 months and my hair is starting to come back

column2: JenninGA33, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: My experience with Mirena was a one time thing that lasted me about 13 months. I  experienced so much pain when I had my Mirena inserted, then my periods stopped for 6 months, then came back with a vengeance. During the time I had my Mirena I experienced problems with cysts on my ovaries multiple times. Finally during my 13th month I started bleeding so bad my doctor had to remove my Mirena. I couldn't have that done again between the pain and the bleeding problems that was enough for me. I'll take a pill everyday.

column2: crb006, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I am 21 with no kids and had it put in as my very first birth control before I got married. I cramped horribly when they put it in and the cramping didn't stop for 3 months!! It was hell putting it in the first time because of the clamp that put on my cervix! Also, I'm 5'11 and weighed 135 lbs, now, almost a year and a half later I'm up to 150lbs and I haven't changed my diet or anything. I worked out all the time and still gained an incredible amount of weight, even with cutting out sugar. I think it's the progesterone because it's linked to weight gain. Anyways, I'm considering getting it out and switching to just birth control pills after only 1 year with it in because it's had more bad side effects than I want even though it's incredibly convenient and has led to more spontaneous sex. Do your research before you try it!

column2: Happy Mirena User, 25-34 on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I love this form of birth control!  I am almost three years into my first device.  I have never had children, so the insertion process was painful, and the cramping lasted for several hours after insertion.  But those were the last cramps I have felt in the past 3 yrs.  Since middle school, I have had severe menstrual cramping that put me out of commission for at least one day a month.  This has meant having to using sick time, laying in bed during vacations, spending hours in the bathroom, etc.  I am 34 now, and the Mirena has completely changed this part of my life; I am so thankful.  I have never experienced weight gain, extra hair growth, acne, etc., as a result of this form of birth control.  All of these things I deal with regularly, and there was no change for me once I began using the Mirena.  Peace of mind knowing that I don't have to worry about remembering to take a pill or change something on a monthly basis is priceless!  I have about 10 girlfriends/family members/co-workers who also use the Mirena.  All are as satisfied as I am.  There are many complaints here about side affects.  None of the women I know who use it complain about any side affects. In fact, it is usually the opposite.

column2: Middle aged momma, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have used this product for 15 years. Had the first one inserted after the birth of my 3rd (and final) child. Initial insertion painful and lots of bleeding but that was temporary and could have been impacted by only being 3 months after her birth. Devices 2 & 3 no pain no bleeding. Relatively no periods in 14 years - no acne - about 10 lbs weight gain - minimal hair loss - until now. I am now 46 yrs. old and hair loss is really bad. Weight gain has been another 10 lbs in last 2 years, sex drive is none exsistent, and not sure where my body is regarding menopause. My hope is that removing the minera will fix it all. (my fear is it will not and I'll end up 50 and pregnant) I have loved this product, but sadly - I think I have reached the point where the side effects outweigh the benefit. It's time to find something else (sigh).

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had my Mirena put in almost a month ago. I'm 22 and haven't had any children. My doctor recommended I get it because I am anemic and she was concerned that I was losing too much blood during my periods. Surprisingly, when it was put in I wasn't in much more pain than my normal cramps during my period. But when the time came for my period to start 2 weeks later I started getting terrible cramps. Normally either a Midol or a heating pad would work to stop the pain, but even with both I was in so much pain that it was hard to get out of bed. I decided to look it up on the internet to see if that was normal and I came across a couple discussions similar to this one. It's a relief to know that the side effects I'm experiencing aren't all in my head. I've noticed terrible cramping, non-stop bleeding (lighter flow though), no motivation/extreme fatigue, depression... I have not ran into acne or weight gain but I'm worried that it'll only be a matter of time. I know everyone's body reacts differently and it may take a while to truly know how my body will adjust to the Mirena, but after reading others' experiences, I can't help but want the thing out... now! I suppose it's serving the purpose my doctor and I set out for by lightening my periods, but at what cost?

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have had Mirena for 6yrs & although very effective in the birth control department, I can not wait to have it removed. Horrible embarrassing Breakouts/Acne its a daily battle. Nothing Helps. I have hot flashes @ 30Yrs old and my hair is falling out so much I use drano regularly to unclog bathroom drains. My period is almost non existent which is a blessing but I think it also has its flaws I am very emotional and lately extremely  depressed. No pain during insertion very happy with not worrying about birth control but I cannot handle the side effects any longer.

I received the Mirena 10/10 for heavy periods, and severe emotional behaviors. I could not take hormonal contraceptives because of my history of severe (daily prescription drug treated) migraines and my cycle was beginning to be unbearable. My last child was born in 07 and in 09 I began having reoccurrent bacteria vaginosis problems (consistently). Since the mirena, my labibdo remains high, no weight gain, migraines haven't increased, periods are much lighter, OH but there is a big BUT!!! Since 10/10 I will have what appears to be periods for at least 3 to 10 days twice a month and most of the time without any warning. Now the procedure was 20 mins but it was guided ultrasound, it felt a little bit more uncomfortable then a pap, holding my inhaling and exhaling when my doc told me to helped. Its something one has to weigh their pros and cons and the reasoning for using this device. I will say that I am exploring other another option that does not involve the use of any non/hormonal drugs,or insertions of devices. I am either going to keep the Mirena or go the surgical route.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am a mom of 2 girls ages 4 and 18 months. Just had my Mirena inserted today.  I was really worried after reading all of the reviews on here. It was not one bit painful.  It did not feel any different than my regular annual exam. My doctor was great and talked me through every step. At the begining of my my appointment I told him I was worried about pain.  He told me that if it was too painful we could just stop and come up with a new plan. Luckily it did not hurt and was very fast.  He then showed me how to check my strings. He gave me a chart to track my cycles for the next few months.  I have not had any pain or cramping at all.  I did have a little tiny bit of spotting, but I have been spotting on and off for the past week so that might not have to do with the Mirena any way. So far so good. I just hope I can ease some fears for others. If I get any adverse reactions, I will definately update my post.

column2: Jsmith, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: During my experience I have  noticed that there is no sexual drive whatsoever.  Very effective method of birth control, but mood swings and depression have been a big deal for me the last five years of my life.

column2: Innocent, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: LOVE it!! I'm on my 2nd one. It's amazing! When I got it in it was like a little pinch, then some mild cramping that day. Would bleed some maybe for a month or so and then periods were lighter and ligher, only needed a liner for years and now no more periods. Yay! Not having to think about birth control is great.

column2: 3N'sinMA, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was so nervous getting the Mirena due to all the negative reviews and I have been so sensitive to birth control pills; gaining weight; acne etc. in the past it was only in desperation I decided to take the plunge and go on the Mirena and I am so glad I did. My period was getting so heavy over the past year I became iron deficient, therefore loosing my hair and getting bald spots and lethargic every month not to mention running to the bathroom every 2 hours to change my tampon and pad from bleeding so much.  Insertion of the IUD was a little painful and spotting for a 2 days after then nothing. My periods so far are great; light bleeding and spotting and thats it. I wish I've done this sooner. Plus my sex drive had increased since being on it my husband loves it too. I can't praise the Mirena enough for giving back my life. Not everyone is the same of course but I just wanted to tell a positive story instead of adding to all the negative reviews that almost scared me away from getting the Mirena and almost missing my chance of getting my life back.

column2: Meagan Taylor, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had the merina inserted today, July 13, 2012. It was extremely painful for me. I cried the whole time. My blood pressure was at 108 before we started & after it was at 136. I was terribly nervous at first, I wish I would of listened to myself. I want it out, I still feel a pain inside. They say in the brochure that if pain persists after 30 min. consult your physisian. I am scared of the pain of it coming out, its shape, they are going to have to do more than just pull it out. My vigina is extremely swollen inside- its not a soft swollen either, it is hard. I am so scared! also I took a bath when I got home & there was a dime size thing that came out, it is not a clot, it is tough like a muscle or something. I am going to go to the hospital tomorrow if I still feel this pain. I am a petite person & my cervix is off to the side, so I am guessing by reading the comments this may be the reason I am having this big of a problem. :(

column2: TrishAnn, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I just had my mirena inserted today i didnt really feel anything it only took about five minutes. I spotted lightly for an few minutes other than that no cramping or heavy bleeding i hope it stays this way.

column2: 25-34 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is my second time getting Mirena. The first time was about 4 years ago and I had to take it out after the first couple of months because I had every single side effect. I decided to get it done again because I kept forgetting to take my pill every day. I had cramping from the very moment the doctor put it in and the cramping didn't go away for about 2 weeks. I still bleed from time to time and it doesn't last more than a couple days. I'm just waiting for more side effects to come, it's been about 2 months now and I'm satisfied this time around. I like that I don't have to worry about taking it every day, never mind every month.

column2: Nina, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had the Mirena for 4&1/2yrs.after I had my 2nd child.I liked that I didn't have to worry about b-control&no periods!But after almost two years I starting feeling the side effects!I never thought of connecting them to the Mirena!I read a quarter of all the comments&I wanted to cry!I'm an active working mom&never changed my diet.I gained 47lbs in 2&1/2yrs.I went from a size 6 to a size 14!I always look &feel bloated like I'm 3-6months preg.I have severe mood swings,irritated,exhausted,feel sluggish all the time,aching bones,headaches,yeast infections,No sex drive,hot flashes,No motivation I'm stuck in the I don't care mode.Which isn't me at all!I don't want to play w/my kids.Icould sleep for hours&sometimes I'm so exhausted &can't sleep,Sometimes I'm depressed,anxiety,nausea,breast hurt like I'm preg.,severe bloating,lower back pain,nervousness,feel like I'm going to have a panick attack,sensitive to noise&light,mental cloudiness,when I did have intercourse It would hurt or I would bleed afterwards,aching legs,vaginal dryness,I have no patience,cold sweats,light-headed,excess water retention,constipation,sometimes I feel like I'm going to lactate& now I'm starting to lose my hair!I can't beleive I never put all these symptoms together before!I blamed it on my age & etc.I just turned 30.I figured my body is changing w/age! Everyone who knows me knows this isn't me!I would always keep my weight in check even after I had my 2 kids I would bounce back! I always had a flat stomach! Now I always look & feel pregnant! My marriage almost ended multiple times & this year has been the worse!My husband curses this thing! He's the one that felt like ever since I had the Mirena I changed tremendously!That's what brought me to this site. I want my life back I want this dam thing out NOW! It's evil!My husband & my kids want me back! I'm afraid of getting it out I hope the're able to just pull it out.Please I know every ones body is different&some people love it but do ur homework!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Turned sideways on me. Strings are missing and I have fluid in my endo. Dont recommend to anyone. Also caused me to have severe acne. Hate this thing!!!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Terrible Experience - Do not use.  This Company and Product are terrible. Caused a perforated uterus and needed $15k surgery to remove.  Bayer is claiming this is a known risk.  I don't think people understand the true risks.

column2: Pz, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This was the best option for me. No pain and most important, no pregnacy. Also no weight gain nor facial acne. Going 4 years strong so its almost time to make my next choice.

column2: almichellea, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I'm an almost 22 year old female- no children. I had my Mirena placed Friday morning, it is now Monday afternoon. During placement I had intense cramping... Nothing I would like to experience again soon but definitely something that is tolerable. I have had very painful to mild cramping since placement... Ibuprofen helps! I have some back pain and am tired but I had started my placebo pill week the day before I came in for placement so I know that I am on my period now. I have pretty heavy bleeding and mood swings like I typically do with my period. Hoping the cramping will lighten up by the end of the week... So far very happy although I am very uncomfortable.Well update if things change! Two friends(my age and also no children) are very happy with their Mirena's. One had pretty heavy bleeding for 3 months after placement- but she had an abortion a few weeks prior and bleeding is mostly due to abortion. The other had cramping and spotting- but no period since. I am a little discouraged reading about all these early twenty with no children reporting they had to have theirs taken out due to complications... staying hopeful!Good Luck!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I had the Mirena removed 10 days ago after 7 months on it - and I'm sooo relieved. It was highly recommended to me by my best friend as well as my gynecologist both of whom are on their 2nd device. Unfortunately, I hated it. Reasons: 1. Worst skin of my life,I started getting one zit after another about 2 months into it after never having had problems with acne before (I'm 35). The skin was terribly greasy all the time and my face also looked puffy. 2. Facial hair growth (noticeable mustache and peach fuzz around my chin). 3. Bristly, extremely fast growing hair under my arms, in pubic area and on my legs. I went back on Nuvaring, which I'd used for 4 years prior to the Mirena and can highly recommend, and thank God after 10 days I look like myself again - skin and hair are back to normal. Unfortunately, the ugly discolorations from the zits are still there but fading thanks to Origins Dr. Weil Mega Bright Serum. From what I've read online, I believe my symptoms were due to excess androgen levels caused by the progestin-only hormone used in the Mirena. Personally, I will not recommend the Mirena to anyone.

column2: Jennifer, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I had mirena inserted after the c-section birth of my twins. I also had a vaginal delivery of my older son 3 1/2 yrs prior. I have had mirena in for over a year. So the good news is I'm not pregnant. So it works. But it's complicAted. Insertion was pretty painless but I started bleeding heavily on the way out of the office. Proceeded to have a heavy period for 3 months but could not use a tampon as I was breastfeeding therefore very dry vaginally. I proceeded to have random spotting every day for 8 months and still randomly spot. Everything is random and extreme now. I get a period every 3 months or so, and though I never need anything more than a reg tampon it can last two weeks. The only reason I can give for this is I breastfed my twins through one yr and still do am/pm. Breastfeeding thins the uterine lining as does mirena. So nothing can accumulate in there. It just falls out. Gross. Wish I got my tubes tied. Will be interesting g to see if things even out when I stop breastfeeding entirely.

column2: NayPar84, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: So far I have seen that everyone who has never had kids had terrible experiences with Mirena. I have 2 kids and got the Mirena 6 weeks after I vaginally delivered my second child. I felt very moderate cramping while she was inserting it. After insertion, I had my cycle for about 3 or 4 days then it stopped. Since I have had Mirena, I have not had any complications, from time to time my husband will feel it, but that depends on the position. My periods are almost obselete. I have one 2-3 times a year and when I do, I spot lightly and it only lasts off and on for 3-4 days. I love my Mirena. I am still on the fence about getting a new one inserted, I want another kid and then I don't.

I got the Mirena over a year after my son who I had vaginally and it was the worst pain in my life. I couldn't even get up after. I laid there for at least ten minutes sobbing before attempting to stand up. My Gyno had a hard time placing it and said it's because I have a tilted Uterus and why it was so painful for me. Since then I stopped my heavy periods and spot sometimes. I cramp often on certain sides of my stomach and after sex. I've had it for over 3 years now. My boyfriend loves it and never felt it before. I really do love it but once my time is up I'm not getting it placed again because i'm too scared to go through that pain again and I have a high pain tolerance.

column2: ARK, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm 30 and have one child via a c-section. All these reviews almost talked me out of getting mirena, but I am so glad I did get it. Insertion was a little painful but no worse than really bad cramps. I had very light bleeding for a couple of days. The next month I had a light period for a little over a week and nothing since. It's been 3 months and I'm totally happy with mirena!

column2: jevausie, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: If you are considering Mirena, do NOT be scared off by negative reviews! Read on for details, but I certainly don't think there's remotely enough pain involved to avoid this device, at least not if you have a competent doctor!I'm almost 23, and - after extensive research - asked to be prescribed Mirena to treat my very irregular periods since suffering a second trimester miscarriage 2 years ago. The birth control aspect is a major plus. I had Mirena inserted almost 2 weeks ago, which is the only reason I only gave it 4 stars for effectiveness, as I haven't had it long enough yet to judge that.For those worried about the pain... don't be. Insertion was certainly not comfortable, but it was far from unbearable, at least for someone like me who has been pregnant in the past. For the record, I did not have any pain killers before or right after insertion, and it was performed 4 days into my cycle. Dilation of my cervix did not hurt one iota. The clamp used to pull the uterus into the proper position for insertion causes moderate cramping, so that wasn't too pleasant, but was not even as bad as period cramps. The only point where I felt even noteworthy pain was the brief "pop" when the insertion device made it around a bend in my uterus that had been causing the doctor trouble... that was a fairly sharp jolt of pain for a few seconds, but it wasn't tear-jerking or anything like that. As soon as the clamp, speculum, and inserter were removed, I felt nothing but very mild cramping which lasted one day and went away the second I took a Midol.I spotted very lightly (only a nickel-sized dot in a pantyliner every few hours) for the first week, and now only notice light traces of blood when I wipe. I have not had any pain related to the Mirena since. I cannot detect any side effects from the hormones. I can't feel the device at all, except for the strings if I check for them, and they're very unobtrusive. They even get softer with time.Mirena is great so far!

column2: rach, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: awsome aside from spotting for the first month,very happy with it.

column2: Jeanie, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Ihad Mirena inserted about 3 and a half months ago. I am 35, and I have not ever been pregnant. The insertion was uncomfortable, but I started having terrible cramping after about 10 minutes. These cramps lasted for about 4 or 5 hours. I lightly bleed almost all of the time now, and am hoping that this stops soon. In the time I have the Mirena, I have only had probably 2 or 3 weeks of not bleeding at all. If this continues, I will have it removed.

column2: helpme4560, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My mother forced me to get mirena about 6 months ago. I never wanted it, but the 'alternative' she was spouting was getting my tubes tied - which is an an insane idea for a 24 year old. I agreed to insertion b/c I've always had heavy periods... BAD IDEA. It was inserted during my period about 6 months ago. Since the insertion, I've had a lot of trouble completely emptying my bladder (and have begun to leak), my genitals have swollen and itch and burn like the fires of hell, and my skin comes off when I wipe... Not to mention my mood swings make me dizzy. Apparently I'm having an allergic reaction - I'm getting it removed as soon as possible but there may be lasting effects. I HATE MIRENA.

column2: Rachael L., 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am 25 and I have 2 kids but never delivered vaginally. The insertion was horrible. Honestly one of the worst pains I have felt. Had horrible cramps for about a day after but they eventually eased up now i cant tell its in until I have sex.

column2: Eng123, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I got the mirena placed about three weeks ago!!!! It did cause some xrampin while being inserted but was nothing major and worth worrying about!!!! After the day I had no cramping but still experiance some spotting but the doctor said thats normal!!! My partner did feel it a couple times during intercourse but rarely is that a problem!!!! Overall its an excellent choice for birth control and I would recommend it!!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This did not hurt when having it inserted! My periods were very irregular for the first 3-4 months after. My only complaint....IT CAME OUT ON IT'S OWN after 3 years. I had no signs of infection and there was no explanation as to why it came out. I plan on having another on put in place. For me personally it was a great choice in birth control...2 kid's is enough for me ;)

column2: Dr. Heels, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I got Mirena when I was 19 after I had my son and have had it for 5 years now. It is time for me to take it out and I am gladly getting a new one. My doctor put it in at my 6 week check up and it did hurt but it wasnt too bad. Afterward my body took some time to adjust but I ABSOLUTELY LOVED my outcome. My cycle had stopped completely! It may soud scary to some but for a person whos cycle was very long (7-10 days) and heavy (had to wear pads and tampons at the same time)I was more than happy. I did have occasional pelvic pain and my partner said he felt it alot during intercourse but other than that it's great! I have herd some horror stories but everyone is different. Based on my experience I would recommend it.

column2: Jabasmo, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Alright...I don't know what everyone's deal with insertion is.  It didn't hurt AT ALL. I have a very very very low pain tolerance and I could barely feel anything. The dr did spray a numbing spray though. I also got it inserted at my six week appt after my baby was born. Initially I was going to do the paragard but after going over it with my dr, we decided mirena was best due to bad periods. I will say that I was extremely extremely uncomfortable for about five hours after insertion.  Horrible cramps. I was just thankful I am on maternity leave and didn't have to work after.   My advice  is to get some help that day if you have small kids.

column2: Lady, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had Mirena inserted 1 week ago and have not had any problems. After reading all the horror stories that people wrote I was having second thoughts about getting Mirena. Im glad I didn't listen and decided to go through with it. I did experience cramps after the procedure but not any pain and it only lasted that day. I only spotted for about 3 days. My experience has been a great one so far.

column2: Krissy, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Mirena was the perfect choice for me.  21 months ago at age 19, I had the device inserted.  I have never been pregnant, although if you have delivered children vaginally it does decrease the discomfort of insertion.  If you can schedule your appointment during your period, that helps a great deal, too, as your cervix is more pliable.  I had the quick procedure during my period and experienced a deep, cramp-like feeling during and then menstruation and cramps for about three more days.  Since then, my period has slowed so that I spot about three days every few months, and I have never experienced any sort of pain again.  Couldn't be more satisfied!

column2: muffy_14, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am 22 years old, and never had kids. I had the Mirena inserted five weeks ago. The insertion was excruciating. I remained in a great deal of pain for 3 weeks.For two weeks the pain woke me up at night. By the fourth week I experienced bouts of extreme cramping. Crampiness continued into my fifth week checkup. As my doctor examined me, she realized I was in a great deal of pain as my fist clinched at my sides. She ordered an ultrasound. The ultrasound showed that it was a bit twisted. I decided to have it removed that day. It turns out the IUD was twisted very awkwardly. The pain ceased immediately after removal.

column2: momof4, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I wanted to comment on my experience with insertion because I have read so many "horror stories" and I thought someone should post if she had a good experience.I had mirena inserted at 2:10 yesterday afternoon.  I had just finished my period 2 days ago.  The appointment took 5 minutes and was painless.  My doctor talked me through every step of the process.  She did a pelvic check, used a local topical numbing agent (similar to what the dentist used before using the needle).  She told me to expect a cramp (never felt it) and then told my I would experience another cramp when the product was placed.  I asked her to tell me when she was placing it so that I could brace myself and she told me she already placed it.  I never felt a thing.  Afterwards, I had cramping for a couple of hours and spotted for the evening.  I woke up this morning and the cramping is gone and I am not spotting anymore.I should let you know that I have 4 children and all were delivered vaginally without any medication for pain.  Maybe that is why this was so simple for me.  I will let you know if I experience any side effects as time goes on.

column2: Female  (Patient)
column9: Hardly hurt at all, I think the "pain" has to do with one's pain tolerance. I've had two kids, and the Mirena was a perfect choice for me. The insertion was practically painless and I've had no complications at all. Very glad with my birth control decision.

column2: Malia, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I got Mirena yesterday, insertion was not too bad, but after I got home for about 6 hours the cramping was horrible. It felt like I was having a miscarriage. The cramping has almost completely went away, only minor spotting that has stopped now.

column2: Jess, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have had my mirena in since Nov 2011. Whe it was inserted it wasnt any worse than a bad menstral cramp, and then it was over. Before I went back for my 1 month check up I could feel it move once in a while, but haven't felt anything since then. First couple periods were fairly heavy, but nothing out of the normal. Since then I might spot for 1-2 days every 2 months, but nothing else.Overall it has worked very well for me, and I don't have any complaints. And being a very busy mother of 3, this has been great.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: No previous pregnancies, intense pain/ cramping for about 2 minutes while being inserted and after that, just minor cramps for 3 hours. Taking Ibuprofen prior to insertion did not help.  Light spotting for first 5 days.

column2: cathy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: when will the bleeding stop

column2: Galina, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Horrible!!!Removed in 25 days: constant pain, bleeding, hair loss, mood swings, acne, back pain..It's a TORTURE!!!!DO NOT USE IT!

column2: monkeylove, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I Just wanted to give my experience with the Mirena IUD. I am a very nervous person as it is and when my NP said that this would be a good option for me along with my mom I decided to go for it. First of all I have a LOW PAIN tolerance and am a big baby, but I did survive the insertion! The way it was inserted was over 3 total cramps the first one was mild and wasn't that bad, then the second cramp/part of the insertion was the most painful and I had to tell the doc to wait a moment for the 3rd cramp/part/insertion...after the second one you will probably want it done and over with so the third cramp was mild like the first. Overall the procedure was about ten minutes, very short!:) but it is painful like a cramp pain, and I did get a little light headed after the second cramp/part. Right after the procedure I was a little whoozey but was suprised with the fact i had NO cramping. Every body is different though but I even went to the gym the next day so far it has been a great experience and I do suggest it for women seeking an easy BC method. I hope this has been helpful and I hope this stays a positive experience. P.S. I have had little spotting as well. Also I have had no children. Women with children may experience less pain w/procedure.

column2: Me, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I got the Mirena 6 days ago . Ever since I got it I have not stopped bleeding and have had bad stomach craps, back pain, nausea, and dizziness. I went to the doctor today to have it removed cuz I new my body wasn't adjusting to this birth control. When I got there right away the doctor is trying to make me feel guilty about removing it cuz it cost $850.00, but i was in so much pain I told her I'm sorry but I dont want it anymore. So when she goes to take it out it had moved down into the cervix and that's what has caused me pain. She then said that it was a good decision I came in. I knew something was wrong. I'm going to stick to pills. It was so painful when it was inserted the first time I thought I was going to faint. I'm not going through that again.

column2: Mamamel, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Love, love, love, my mirena, I had it inserted in 2007 after my 3rd baby, it was uncomfortable.for a couple of days, I did have oeriods for first 2 years, very sporadic. I did have a few.cysts about 2 years in, but the benefits far outweigh the side effects. I have not had a period at all in the last few years, every now and then I will spot for a day or two (maybe every 6-8 months. It is time to have it replaced, I have been considering essure or paragard, but I love not having a period. FYI..Bayer/mirena offers a payment plan! Not a lot of people(even docs, mine didn't) know about this program, you make payments directly to mirena, then they send your device to your doc office with your name on it. All that you pay doc for is insertion!! The have a couple options, monthly and four payments. it is much more affordable this way, especially for those of us without ins.

column2: drasadaf, 25-34 Female  (Patient)
column9: Awesome contraception for today's woman.

column2: abby0887, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had my IUD place about two months ago, went back to my doctor at beginning of this month they finally decided to do another ultrasound and see why i been having pain they found a cyst and she said she was going to check in about six weeks and see if it goes away, my husband has been complaining about it since i got it inserted so i mentioned to my doctor and she said she could cut the threads which she did but now i guess it made it worse he says it feels like a needle poking and basically we are not having any intercourse due to this, i don't know if she cut the treads too short or if he is just too sensitive but we never had any problems til now, i had cyst before but never as big as this one and the pain is horrible, period wise i probably only had a full week with no bleeding, but my doctor says it's normal and that it will go away, not sure if this is the right birth control for me since i have polycystic ovarian syndrome and she said this would help but i feel that it making it worse! any comments about this, has anyone experience the same??

column2: mrushlow, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I got my Mirena Sept of 2009 after the birth of my first chile. Getting it wasn't bad. I went about 4 months before my body got used to it then all of a sudden periods went away its now may of 2012 and i have gotten a severe infection on my cervix, uterus, UTI, and cysts on my ovaries, also my string disappeared... severe pain during intercourse and I might have to have it surgically removed. The Mirena was great for me until this happened. I am worried this could affect me having a second child. I won't have it put back in. I guess for some women it works great as it did for me in the beginning... but for me now... NEVER again!!!

column2: ljp, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Wonderful experience! I have had mine for just over 5 years. It is officially time to have it removed and my doctor has reminded me that it is not adequate for birth control any longer. Based on my age and the fact I have no partner it would have to be an immaculate conception for me to get pregnant at this time. We believe I am probably post-menopausal but are not sure. I can leave it in longer if I want, I have had no spotting or periods since it was placed. I'm reluctant to have it removed for fear of having to start dealing with periods again. I think I want to test my hormone levels first to be sure that at least at that moment they appear to be p-m. I do recommend it for anyone with irregular, or heavy periods. My daughter got one shortly after I did and has only had mild spotting throughout her time on it. She had a little cramping  at time of insertion and still gets a little cramping now and then at her time of month but nothing like she used to. We both recommend it.

column2: KaeBrae, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I am SHOCKED to see so many horror stories!My Mirena was placed mid-Feb 2009 (over 3 years ago). I've had 2 kids (2007 & 2009) by c-section...placement was uncomfortable, but not grossly painful and I was just a bit crampy the rest of the day, but I also only took Ibuprofen after my c-sections, no other pain meds (as a disclaimer for my pain tolerance). I have 3 days of spotting very month, without cramping. I check my threads every month and have no problem finding them. Mirena has in no way affected any aspect (mood, sex drive, ect) of my life negatively. I have a planned time frame for removal so we can have our 3rd and finally baby and after that I will have Mirena replaced until we make the decision about permanent birth control.  Hope this helps other women know that not everyone's expierence has been awful or scary!!

column2: Rita sue, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have had this for about 30 days I have spotted everyday. I got this so I wouldn't have a period. Frustrating I'm going for my check up this week. I also cramp a least once a day.

column2: car16, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I got pregnant!  After 18 months of having it...I became pregnant and miscarried within the first trimester.  It has been 6 months now & I have bled for 10-14 days each month since and have had debilitating ovarian cysts each month as well.  One cyst was actually 7cm!  I battled depression over the lost pregnancy and would not recommend this product.

column2: Genevieve, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have had thr mitena for almost one year. I am nineteen, gealthy and active. Insetrion was not bad but the year has beenvwry long with mirena. First off, my boyfriend is eight inches and always complains he feels the plastic hitting his penis. Sex has become incomfortable and some positions painful. Also prior to the iud I never had a single infection. This year I have had over seven (mostly bacterial vaginosis) now I am at risk for pelvic inflamamitory disease and am getting it removed. I would not recommend it.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I got the Mirena IU 2 months after I had my son in 2007. I have had it in for 5 years now and today was the day I had to have it removed. I choose to insert a new Mirena IU. The pain was worse with the second time then the first, however, I also didn't take any pain medicine. I had no problems and honestly it wasn't that bad. I can have it in for another 5 years and I don't have to worry about anything. I have a check-up in one month to make sure everything is fine. My husband and I want to have another baby in about 2 years so we will take it out then. I still get my periods and they are light. I like the mirena because it doesn't stop you from having periods. I have always had my period every month. They were lighter and helped with cramps. I like this birth control because it still sheds the blood so it's not like for 5 years I have "backed up" blood. Sounds gross, but I wanted to make sure that wouldn't happen because I don't think its healthy NOT to have a period for almost 5 years. My doctor says I will most likely have cramps for a few days and that is normal. After a week they should be gone and have no pain. I LOVE it because now my husband and I don't have to worry and I don't have to stay up all night thinking, "did I take my pill last night?"

column2: adonal01, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had the IUD put in about 5 months after having my second child. The cramping and pain was so bad afterwards I was useless to my two kids the rest of the night. The following two weeks I had sharp flashes of pain that were bad enough to make me wince. My doctor had scheduled a standard four week check up after insertion of the IUD. In that appointment she could not find it. After the next two weeks of scheduled ultrasounds and x-rays they finally found it. According to the x-ray it embedded, as the Mirena website called it, leaving it sticking out of my uterus.  I then had to schedule an outpatient laparoscopic surgery for them to go in and take it out.  When they went in the Mirena was laying in my abdomen completely outside of my uterus and the hole it came through was already healed through.

column2: clp82, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I  have been on mirena for about 6 months. Im young and want to be more active. I had horrible pain after getting it in but things got better after the first month. I found more I did in a day the worse id feel the next. I have been to the doctor multiply times for abdominal pain. I dont  like being touched anymore and im very moody. The pains I haave experience are to the point of my doctor recommendinng I go to ther E.R. I choose mirena bc im forgetful and cant remember  to take the pill and also cheaper in the long run, not mention it will last for 5yrs. I will be having it removed soon. The experience ive had in the last 6 months have not been what I  expected and I cannot deal with the constant pain fr another  4 yrs not to mention upsetting my fiance due to my mood swimgs and  not wanting to be touched. Im just not the same person annyone. Its changed my life. I hope all that choose to havve  mirena have a better experience than ivr had.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Just had Mirena put in this morning.  Was a little concerned after reading some of the reviews about the cramping and the pain of it being inserted. I think the best description of this for me was just uncomfortable. Nothing painful or that I couldn't handle. I did take a 600mg motrin about an hour before my appt. I haven't had any cramping or any other issues throughout the rest of the day. Hopefully the rest of my experience will be just as good.

column2: PeaSoup, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am 38, and have never given birth.  My doctor recommended Mirena for my long and heavy periods.  (My periods were 10-12 days long, and I would go through at least 2 boxes of super sized tampons.)  Honestly, the procedure itself was the worst pain I have ever felt, I almost passed out from it.  I was given a prescription for 800 mg ibuprofen to take during and after, it didn't help much.  The aftermath wasn't much better, I had moderate to severe cramping off and on for about a month afterwards.  I had light to moderate bleeding for 5 weeks afterwards.  I have now had Mirena for 10 weeks and I never thought I'd say it, but I love it.  I think I've had one period, but it was so light, I wasn't sure if I was spotting or what.  I haven't gained any weight (and I like to eat) and no complexion or personality changes like others have complained about. I don't know if it's relevant, but I didn't experience any of those side effects when I was on the pill many years ago either.So, in summary:  if you are considering this option and haven't given birth, see if you can get some kind of stronger pain med, and be patient with the cramps and bleeding afterward.  I have been very pleased and look forward to easier periods for the next 5 years!

column2: mnqwzhr, 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I love this birthcontrol! I use to take pills but I could never remeber it and I had really bad periods so I got mirena but when I got it,it was very painful (never had a child) after that lot have cramping then 1 month having a period after that  I had no more periods and I only had for 7 months now and love it!

column2: Katrina, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I choose this for birth control a year after I had my son. U don't like birth control pills and we were not ready for another baby. I had it the full five years and lived it as I had only spotting some months and other would go for several without having anything. When the time was up I had a new one inserted. It hurt worse than the first one taking it out then putting the new one in. A lot of cramping and soreness with this one that I did not have the first go. A year or so went by and I started having blood pressure problems, skin problems, and tiredness. Absolutely no sex drive!! My breasts got to where they always hurt! I talked to my doctored and they both said that the mirena wasn't the cause........ I wonder! I made me an appointment to have it removed and it came out the night before on its own!!! Also felt like I had to pee all the time!! Since its come out..... I have a general feeling of relief! It's hard to explain but I feel like me again. It's been two weeks and I'm hoping I can get off the blood pressure meds and get on with my life. It was a great option for me but I don't feel like the doctors were really honest about side effects! They ignored anything bad or negative about mirena!! Good luck ladies!!!!!

column2: Cara, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've had my Mirena for almost 3 years now.. I do not recommend this method. My first year was great! My periods stopped, but then came the Cramping,depression,I can't stand to be touched hugged ect.. This IUD has really changed who I am.. Not to mention I was just diagnosed with Pelvic Inflammatory disease because my body is now rejecting it. I'm in constant pain. Intercourse is painful and I don't want it anymore. I cannot wait to have this thing removed, but fear that no other Birth Control is as affective as the IUD. I am in no means trying to scare anyone, just letting you know what my experience has been like. I am a mother of two.

column2: NikkiMax, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I got my Mirena placed 4 yrs ago, I was 25 and never had children, the implantation was uncomfortable and the cramping afterwards was severe. After the 1st 24hrs everything great, had very mild spotting maybe once every few month, never had any pregnancy scares, occasional breast tenderness, otherwise it was ok and didn't have any of the emotional side effects you get with BC pills.Unfortunately after the 1st year I started developing other side effect. I started getting very dark and thick facial hair, a small patch on my chin, then another, then the upper lip hair started getting darker. And I developed severe acne. Never had bad acne before, mild break-outs around my period, 1-2 deep cyst a year, nothing horrible, but now I have about 3 cysts a month plus multiple other breakouts. I was put on spironolactone, doxycycline, retin A, glycolic acid, etc, etc, etc, and nothing has worked - refuse to try Accutane due to the side effects. While I loved not having my period for 4 years and did not have to worry about taking pills or anything, the man hair and acne scars are too much now. I can't undo the damage that has been done. I have seen too many other women have this same problem so taking it out is my only option right now. I got it out today and a Paragard placed. Once again the insertion was very unpleasant and wouldn't recommend doing anything but lay around the day of and I have some mild spotting but I'm optimistic my skin will have a chance to heal. I'll post about my Paragard experience after the recommended 90 days to let my body acclimate. Hopefully my body will like this one better :-/

column2: NatalieS, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had my Mirena put in a week ago. I've never had kids so my cervix was not stretched. My doctor actually called it Ft. Knox. :) The insertion was very painful because of this. I would say extreme pain for 2-3 minutes. Once it was in and the clamp was removed, for the next 3 hours I had some bleeding and pretty significant cramps. Day 2 and 3 were good, with a steady course of ibuprofen. Day 4 had about an hour long bout of bad cramping but then fine afterwards. The remainder of the days I've had minor cramping, but have stayed on top of taking the ibuprofen religiously to make sure it doesn't get out of control. I've felt very tired over the past week and am not sure if it's from this or from a cold that I've had. Overall, things are going well, but ready to be off the ibuprofen and feeling normal. I was also really concerned about expulsion for the first 48 hours as it seems higher with kidless people. :) I checked my strings everyday and for those who are concerned about this, just because you can't feel them doesn't mean it's not there. Try repositioning and trying again or try again later.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I gave birth to twins in December 2011 by C-section.  My first Mirena was inserted in March this year.  Insertion EXTREMELY painful, because my cervix never dilated, they had to dialate it in the office.  Once inserted, mild cramping for about 5 minutes.  My husband could feel the strings, so on my string check appt, instead of cutting strings, my GYN tucked them.  My husband hasn't felt them since.  Also, to reduce the side effect of spotting, my GYN gave me Loestrin birth control pills.  Took Loestrin for 10 days, and spotting has pretty much stopped.  All in all, I would recommend Mirena.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had Mirena for the last 2.5 years and I love it. Yes the insertion hurt badly but I went home, took Midol, and went to sleep. The next day I was slightly sore but it was definately bearable. I have had a wonderful experience with it other than the insertion but overall it has been worth it. I plan to keep it in for the full 5 years and then think about my options then. But I would and have recomended it to my friends.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Absolutely fantastic!!!!!!!!! I have had Mirena for 6 years now and I love it! I have an extremely light period every few months but that's it! I have had no side effects. Def the best birth contol out there!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I felt the need to post my experience as I almost didn't go through with Mirena after reading the reviews. I had it inserted on Monday. It was not the most comfortable experience, but it was not that bad. Intense cramping for about 2 minutes while being inserted and after that, just minor cramps for a few hours. Nothing that Motrin couldn't fix. When I woke up the next day, I was fine. No cramping, no spotting, nothing. I have not had any side effects. I have only had it in for a few days, but everything appears to be great. If I do get any side effects in the coming weeks, I will certainly update my post. I just wanted to share my experience because after reading most of the horrible reviews online, I was terrified! Every woman is different and you have to make the decision to have it inserted based on YOUR body, not other peoples reviews.

column2: thudson, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: i am looking forward to getting this device removed after 1.5 years.  i haven't felt myself for about a year and a half, I've been depressed, angry, on and off pain, 3 out of 4 weeks of spotting.  It's horrible.  I thought this would be a great way to avoid having to have a period, but it's not worth it...not to mention that I have to wear a light maxi pad almost all of the days of the month.  At least before mirena I knew I could go 3 weeks without any worry.  Not to mention that I experience quite a bit of pain before my period...seriously sharp unbearable pain.  It wasn't until Mirena that I started feeling despair and depression as well.  I kept chalking it up to lifes circumstances, or the weather.  But ever since Mirena, I cry at the drop of a hat, or feel sad over next to nothing.  This just isn't me.  I can't wait to be back to normal when I get this thing removed.

column2: bbynpynk12, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: i have unsual periods, i never know when i will have spotting or how long my periods will last. my usual period w/bc pills is 3 days, with this it is off and on for 7-10 days going from spotting to a period with a day or 2 between with nohting. I am thinking seriously about having it removed, the side effects of never knowing and constantly having to carry tampons is so frustrating!!!!!!!!!!

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I got it about three months after giving birth to my first child and I wish someone would have warned me how painful it would be. I had intense cramping pain for about five hours after the initial insertion which eventually faded. My doctor checked me out a week later and I was told that everything was fine. I continued to get abdominal pain that would come and go, and the pain would differ in location (mainly left, right, front). I've had it for a year now and the pain is less then it use to be and usually comes right before I get my period (which is more like spotting than an actual period). I do have side effects: acne, weight gain, lowered sexdrive. And my poor husband gets bruises on his penis sometimes from it. I don't think I'll be having it for very much longer..

column2: kwake208, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I got Mirena because I wanted birth control that also helped to control my periods better because they were very heavy. It did a good job on the birth control part, and my periods were not heavy, BUT they were light and never ended! Every month, I had my period for three weeks and one week without it. I also had a lot of pain when it was put in, but this was due to me never having children before.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Iagave had mirena for over a year now and love it. I had mirena inserted 8 weeks after giving birth. The insertion was nothing to me. I did have spotting for the first 2 months but a panty liner was all I needed. After that my periods gradually stopped. My only complaint is that I have an annoying amount of the leukorrhea discharge lately but that may be from another prescription that I am on since I just recently started noticing it. Based on the reviews, it sounds like women who have had children before have been having better luck with it. It will continue to be my birth control of choice :)

column2: marykate061989, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I had Mirena inserted 5 years ago, a few months after the birth of my daughter. The insertion wasn't too bad. It felt like a severe menstrual cramp and lasted less than a minute. Afterwards, I had some cramping for about a day. I really liked the Mirena for awhile. Before pregnancy, I had experienced long and painful periods. The Mirena eventually stopped my periods all together. I enjoyed not having to think about birth control and not having a period. At this point, I would have recommended the Mirena. When I went to the OBGYN for a check-up two years after getting Mirena, the doctor could not see the strings. I had an ultrasound to confirm that the Mirena was still in my uterus. It was, but it had moved from where it was supposed to be. The doctor told me that it would still be effective although I could not check the strings. For the next three years, I worried constantly about this and about how the doctor would remove the Mirena when the five years were up. I went to my OBGYN four days ago to get the Mirena removed since I had it for five years this month. My doctor could not get it out during my normal exam. I was scheduled for a hysteroscopy, which I had two days ago. I took ibuprofen before I went in. The procedure was painful and lasted a little over five minutes. I had some cramping afterwards. I feel back to normal again today. I do not recommend Mirena because of my experience. I realize that not everyone has to go through this, but my experience was painful and very stressful. I have started Ortho Tricyclen Lo. I am so glad to have the Mirena out of me and I will never get it again.

column2: Moon, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Mirena is probably the best long term and reversible birth control method. No downtime, no weight gain problem for me. I no longer have to suffer a cramp during the first 4 hours of each period because I virtually have no period now. The only issue I had is the on and off light spotting that lasted for 4 months after inserting Mirena, hence I only gave it 4 stars in the Satisfaction category.

column2: hailey , 25-34 on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years
column9: I've had mirena for 5 years and just got another one inserted for another 5 years.I love it.insertion wa likeasuper intense cramp,but only lasted a minute. Bleeding was irregular for 6 months. But it started getting lighter and   less painful until it stopped completely or is virtually non exsistant. I would recommend it  everyone. I love not having periods anymore. And it works

column2: jenn1006, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I don't usually review products but i noticed a lot of reviews for mirena are negative.  so i thought i would let everyone know there are positive outcomes.  I got Mirena placed 4 weeks ago. had very light spotting for about 24 hours after placement and mild cramping.  The first 24 hours were nothing like my first 2 days of my normal periods, much easier.  I normally get large cyst like acne a couple of days before my period and these have completely cleared since the placement!  My skin is actually MUCH clearer.  I have had no cramping or spotting since the first 24 hours after placement.  Yesterday I had some very, very light spotting, breast tenderness, and mild cramping.  I was supposed to start my period 2 days ago.  As of today...nothing.  No spotting, tenderness, or cramping. I suppose i just had my first period after placement! Amazing!! I went from acne, 8+ days of heavy periods, extreme cramping, back aches, moodiness, etc. I can honestly say I feel better and have actually lost a couple of pounds since getting the mirena.  Just keep in mind everyone reacts differently.  There are those who are very greatful for Mirena. So far I have nothing negative to say.  I only gave 4 stars due to the fact I have only had it 4 weeks. So far best decision I have ever made absolutely life changing for me..

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
sbrOHio, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I gained 30 lbs in the five years I had the IUD in place, but I stopped breastfeeding and have a history of anxiety which has also been treated with medication for nearly the exact same length of time. I can't fairly say there's a correlation because of too many overlaying factors.Disclaimer aside, my husband complained since insertion that he could feel the IUD during sex, so I had the strings cut shorter. We didn't have to worry about that problem, though, because my sex drive was so low (again, not saying there's a definite correlation). The IUD did embed itself and I had to see my gynecologist to get it removed (two general practitioners tried and failed), but it was painless and quick.The removal was 15 days ago. The first week I experienced spotting and then normal to heavy menstrual flow. On day seven, I began such severe bleeding/discharge that I couldn't go an hour without having an accident--even when I wore an overnight pad and a super absorbancy tampon. It's the sudden surge of the flow that makes the problem so uncontrollable. Nothing can absorb the huge globs fast enough to prevent them from traveling and ruining my clothes and my day several times over.I started a progestin pill two days ago (13 days after IUD removed) to control the discharge/flow. I am now dealing with less fluid and more globs. It's uncomfortable, frustrating, unpredictable... I have worked from home since Tuesday, when I had to deal with a junior-high moment in the middle of a 2 hour meeting, complete with a sweater tied around my waist during a humiliating exit. Not ok. I loved not having periods for 5 years, but after the removal and subsequent research, I can see many parallels with women's stories about side effects and experiences. I would never use an IUD again.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Its been over a year since i have had it and i have not been dissapointed! The insertion process was not nice, at all (never have been pregnant), but it was fairly quick. I felt icky for about a week after. After 2 months of having it, i stopped having a period. It was weird to not have a period but now im used to it. The threads are in place and has been incredibly effective. I dont have to remember to take a pill, patch, or get a shot. I still get some symptoms of a period, every month (bloating, moodiness, water retention). Other than that, i've had no issues!! i love the iud!

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had mirena inserted 4 years ago after the birth of my first child. After giving birth to him, I was back to my pre-pregnancy weight. For the first few months after insertion, my period lasted 3 weeks out of the month and stayed irregular. I've lost so much hair, it was so bad that within a week, I could probably make a wig. After the cycles became regular I did notice the bleeding was much lighter than before, but my OB-GYN always had problems locating the strings. I also felt emotionally unstable, but I thought it was the baby blues. For the first 3 years, I gained about 10 pounds, not bad considering I was not all that active. From 2011 up until now I have put on an additional 15 pounds unexplainably. I am more active now than I have ever been (working out an hour a day, watching my diet), and I was only able to lose 5 pounds in 6 months. My weight constantly fluctuates, and I am almost always bloated. I also have hair in the weirdest places, like on my chin, my neck, and even around my nipples. My sex drive has decreased tremendously, and I am only 23 years old. With all of this being said, I am getting this evil thing out next week tuesday! I am hoping there are no problems getting it out, as my doctor said she has had many patients get surgery to have it removed, one patient in particular had mirena attach itself somewhere in her abdomen. While yes, this has done its job of preventing pregnancies (although I have also heard stories of it falling out during a heavy period and as a result, causing this person to become pregnant) and has helped my flow (it has become a lot lighter, although sometimes I have skipped months or have longer periods, which my doctor has told me was normal), I do not reccommend this to anyone who has had problems with other hormonal birth control. While everyone is different, I had a horrible experience with this and I can't wait to get it out!

column2: Colipdx, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I read tons of reviews of Mirena before finally taking the plunge. I had REALLY heavy periods after my period returned after having my second child. We had decided to stop having children and the IUD seemed like a good choice. I really wanted my periods gone and this seemed like the best solution on all fronts. I am VERY happy with my experience. I had it put in when my son with 10 months old after a V-BAC. I felt only very mild discomfort and had minimal cramping that night and tinges the next day. Very little spotting as well. My doctor had me come in as my period was ending, which is key to the minimal bleeding I believe. I am now at my first period post Mirena and I am THRILLED! I am basically only spotting, already. Amazing. Last month I had to use a super plus tampon each hour for two days and nights. Now I may only use two for the entire event! I feel so much better while on my period. I did have some period related acne briefly, and some intense carb/salt cravings. So happy I went this direction. I have not gained nor lost any weight and have kept a very close eye on it. I don't detect any change in libido either (higher if anything but with two children we are so tired it is hard to tell!)

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had my Mirena IUD for 3 years now and still baby free :) The insertion was incredibly painful. The nurses did not tell me to take Ibuprofin ahead of time so I was in more pain than most. Once the cramping passed, I haven't had any more issues with my IUD. At my yearly check-ups my doctor checks the strings, and everything is fine. This method of birth control is so simple and effective. I will definitely get it again after my first baby.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I found it to be the most effective birth control on the market . I had no problems with it  for the hole 5 years. I just had it removed and it was painless. I will be getting a new one in 2 days.

column2: Stephanie, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I had Mirena inserted in March of 2011. The insertion was uncomfortable, but bearable. I had cramping afterwards for like an hour or two, but Motrin took care of that. I experienced light brownish discharge for about 4 weeks. After that, my period came super light every month. It never disappeared like I thought it would. In October of 2011, I felt the thread for the first time which alarmed me because I figured that if I hadn't felt it before, it meant that somehow it was not in its correct position anymore. Sure enough, a couple of days later I got a heavy period for about a week. After my period was done, the doctor pushed it back into place. I had an ultrasound and everything looked good. But after that I kept getting a period every month, and finally 2 days ago (March 2012) while taking a shower I felt the thread again. I gave it a light tug and out it came. I don't know if my doctor didn't put it in right, but now I am Mirena free. I plan on looking for other alternatives because the anxiety of not knowing whether the thing was in place or not was driving me insane. I believe it worked until October, but after that initial displacement, everything went downhill. From april to october i did not experience mood swings, or any PMS symptoms, except maybe some bloating. If it had stayed in place, I would have been happy with it, but it did not work for me.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: When deciding to get Mirena, most of the reviews I found were terrifying, or "it works great, I love it". So I wanted to give a detailed review of my experience that has been uneventful so far (5 months post insertion), so other could know what to expect. I'm 26, no children. I had simple, incredibly regular periods that were average flow and short. For me, the insertion (during my period) was uncomfortable, but not unbearable. I bled lightly and cramped for about two weeks.     For the next two months, I spotted lightly constantly. I had never experienced spotting before and expected it to be light bleeding here and there, but it was a constant, thick brown discharge. Kind of gross, but a pantyliner was all that was needed. Also during this time, every few days I would all of a sudden get a serious cramp and would start bleeding. After about twenty minutes, it would just stop instantly. Sometimes I would be aware of a pokey feeling, although that may have been psychosomatic. During this time I feel like my moods got a little abnormal too, but not unbearably so.     After those first two months, I have experienced no cramping or bleeding between periods. At five months, I am still having periods. They are significantly lighter than before, but last longer (about 10 days, compared to 5 days before Mirena). My period "side effects" (PMS, cramping, etc) are also a little different than before. No worse, no better, just different.    The biggest drawback so far is that I have noticed a substantial impact on my libido. It was strong to start with, and it is still there, just... more towards the back of my mind than before maybe. The first couple of months I experienced difficulty with lubrication and reaching orgasm, which had never been problems before. I would say that in the last month that is starting to resolve itself and I feel like I've gotten my body back. I haven't experienced any weight gain, acne, hair loss, etc.

column2: Angie028, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My story started in August 2011.  I went to the eye doctor for a routine exam mainly wanting to get new glasses.  At the appointment some of the questions the doctor was asking I thought was a little strange but it was things that was happening to me and I was just ignoring the symptoms.  Losing my vision when bending over, dizziness, and headaches.  I started with the tests MRI (which was normal) Lumbar Punture (36) and blind spots in my field vision tests.  It was confirmed I had Pseudotumor Cerebri.  My next mission was to find out, why did this happen to me?  No doctor could tell me why so I started my own research.  I'm a CPhT at a hospital so I had alot of info at my fingertips.  I came across birth control and thought this could be a cause, since I had Mirena IUD inserted in October 2010.  All the literature on Mirena does not say anything about Pseudotumor Cereri but Norplant does.  They both have levonorgestrol as the active ingredient.  So I took this to the many doctors I was seeing at the time.  To my surprise no one wanted to hear what I was saying.  When I found out this info I made the appointment to have Mirena removed!  I am currently taking Diamox 1500 mg daily and it's been 5 months since having Mirena removed.  Other than the side effects from the Diamox (tingling sensations,ringing ears,tired all the time) I am getting better.  No one is going to tell me any different that Mirena was not the cause of Pseudotumor Cerebri.

column2: Carrie614, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: It's very effective and easy but it's caused severe depression, insane weight gain, hair loss, exhaustion and who knows what else? I'm sure if works well for some women but know that these side effects are very real and are caused by the Mirena.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: OK for everyone who hasnt had a child do not get this. I went two days ago and was not nearly informed of the excruciating pain i was going to go through. I did not get any numbing or medicine and it was literally the most painful thing i have ever experienced and i have had a lot of procedures. it is day two and i am in pain all day still with horrible cramping. I wouldnt recommed this to anyone. hopefully it gets better but so far im miserable.

column2: Micky, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: The insertion was incredibly painful. Had intermittent cramping and unpredictable bleeding for months. As someone else said, since I gained so much weight, was moody, had no sex drive and might or might not cramp and bleed, it worked GREAT as birth control. I could not get this thing out fast enough even though I really can't afford to go back on pills without insurance. It was that bad.

column2: crystala, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: R.I.P my Mirena :( I had it placed in 2005 when I still had good medical insurance and only had a $25 co-pay.  I have never been pregnant before, but the ob-gyn assured me that I was still a good candidate.  The worst part of the IUD was the insertion and the week or two following.  I was not given any type of pain reliever or numbing agent and forcing my cervix open was the most painful thing I've ever felt.  It was intense, sharp cramps, nothing like the light "period cramps" I was told to expect.  Once it was in it felt like the worst period cramps I'd ever had, X10.  I went home and took a lot of ibuprofen... and continued to do so off and on for the following two weeks.  I'm not sure if it's because I've never been pregnant or if it's that bad for everyone, but it was ugly.  Then came the bliss.  Once I adjusted to the foreign body in my uterus, I came to love my plastic "T" as it relieved me from the annoyance of a having period for 5 blissful years.  I had the occasional light cramping as if a period might be coming, but never had bleeding.  I saw slight pinkish tinge when I wiped a few times over the years but never a flow.  In April 2011, my Mirena's 5 year residency came to an end and I paid $110 to have it removed.  I desperately wanted to replace it with another, but my school district's insurance plan changed and I didn't have $1,400 to shell out... So I'm making do with the Camila pill.

column2: SenoniMarie, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I got Mirena inserted about 2 years ago and for me the insertion part was not so bad bc my gyn numbed me up. I did experience a lot of cramping afterwards which had me laid up the rest of the day. Mirena is fantastic in terms of it does its job to protect you from pregnancy without thinking about taking something. For me, I've noticed an excessive weight gain which I cannot lose, my sex drive is non-existent and my partner and I are in our early 20s. I'm moody all the time and lazy and I do have irregular periods along with fluids which I'm pretty sure is abnormal bc who secretes that much? I certainly never did. I'm conflicted bc I like not remembering to take a pill or change my BC but at the same time my relationship is suffering plus it hurt getting it so I would hate to go through all that again. I would recommend it only bc everyone's body is different but I'm certainly going to speak with my PCP next month about all my issues with it.

column2: GAtoNC, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I am writing this as a follow-up to my review yesterday.  I had my second Mirena inserted just this morning- not bad AT ALL.  Evidently there is some kind of little device that holds your cervix in place (in addition to the speculum) while they insert the IUD, and I had some mild cramping whenever that was in place, but nothing that I would call truly painful.  The procedure probably took about 5 minutes.  I understand that women may react very differently, but in my opinion, the mild and short discomfort of having Mirena inserted is totally worth it, considering you don't have to worry about birth control for 5 whole years.  Hope that helps ease some peoples' fears!

column2: GAtoNC, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had the Mirena inserted in 2007 when my first child was about 6 months old.  The procedure was mildly uncomfortable, but (for me) nothing incredibly painful as others have described.  I had some menstrual-like cramping that day but was able to go to work after my appointment.  I had spotting/light bleeding for about 3 months after insertion, and then, NO periods whatsoever until I had it removed in 2009 when we started trying to conceive again.  I was breastfeeding at the time of insertion, so that may have contributed to the absence of a period.  After removal, I had one normal period and became pregnant the following month with our second child.  I did not experience weight gain (I actually lost weight pretty easily when dieting/exercising) or any of the other horrible side effects that some have described, although there were 1-2 days per month that I would feel particulary crabby (I'm assuming this would have been my normal "PMS-ing" time if I had had a period).  Overall, I loved the Mirena, and I'm having my second one inserted tomorrow.

column2: Robyn, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
