In june 2011 I took a pregnancy test bc I had gained 7 lbs and I was pregnant. I did lose the baby but started having lots of pain with the Mirena. I had it removed and i didn't feel a thing. I bled for a couple days after and then stopped. Its been 7 weeks and I still havent had another cycle. And no I'm not pregnant.

column2: Wendy, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Uncomfortable to have put in but not intolerable. I bled for a couple weeks very lightly in the beginning. I haven't had a period in over 3 years, just some spotting maybe once a year or so. Mirena does make me very moody and irritable at times though. I do experience some cramping every now and again. Overall, it was worth getting

column2: Jackie, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I've had Mirena for a year, and have lost hair, had infections from staph, ear, bladder,sinus, pneumonia, and strep.  I have never had any of these before this IUD was placed. And all within a year? No energy, weight gain, dull backaches, were enough-made the appt today to have it removed..  I will not recommend

column2: gauri, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had mirena iud 6 weeks ago.First 3 weeks i had bleeding after that i was fine,no pain,no weight gain,no acne,no mood swing.I am very happy with it.

column2: cjones, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had the mirena inserted after my 2nd child was born. It was put in at my 6 wk checkup. I felt that I wasn't warned about how painful the insertion would be. It was VERY painful and it continued to be painful for a few hours afterwards. The following day the pain was gone and I had very light spotting for a few weeks, then nothing. I'm very satisfied and happy that I don't have to think about birth control for 5 long years. Five years is a long time in comparison to a few hours of discomfort. I recommend.

column2: sarah, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I worked at a women's clinic for several years and spoke to many women who were very happy with this method. But after reading so many negative reviews of Mirena (that almost discouraged me from getting one myself), I decided to add myself into the chorus of voices that have had a positive experience with this form of bc.  This is not to invalidate the bad experiences some women have had with this method, but to let women interested in Mirena know that bad experiences are a small minority, and overrepresented on this site.  I have  suffered with dysmenorrhea for 20 years, since my first period, and was not only looking for a highly effective bc, but something that could help manage the pain (monthly vomiting, diarrhea, occasional fainting). Mirena has done that for me.  My first period has come and gone, and the pain was cut in half.  I imagine it will continue improve. I do want to say that while the insertion was fairly easy for me(I had a shot of lidocaine in my cervix, which also helps dilate it), the first month (especially the first week) was definitely uncomfortable. The cramps never got as bad as during my period, but they were definitely no walk in the park. Schedule your insert at a time when you have few demanding activities or work for at least a few days. But in the long run, I'd do it over again in a heartbeat.

column2: MommaGina, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had the Mirena inserted on Aug 10,2011. Today is Aug 28 and I have been in the hospital for a full week because of blood clots in my lungs that can;t be attributed to anything else but the Mirena IUD. My body expelled the device in a huge nasty blood clot 4 days ago. Thankfully that was not painful, and I feel much better after it left me. The gyn at the hospital says she has never seen this problem with Mirena before, but my regular Dr has reported my problem with the IUD to the FDA. I DO NOT recommend this product.. I am seriously thinking of finding an attorney.

column2: Britt, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I got Mirena in Dec 2010, I had it removed Aug 2011. Overall I didn't have near as many side-effects that I read about in the reviews. The insertion was painful, my doc told me it would be more painful for me since I'd never had children. It sucked, but some Ibuprofen and a heat-pack took care of it in a day or two. I had a few light periods the first two months and then after that no period at all, some very light spotting every once in a blue moon.The biggest annoyance for me was the occasional cramping. It wouldn't be more than the usual period type cramps so it was tolerable, but it definately got old after a while. I experienced slight weight gain, especially in the last few months. I am a very active person and it was definately out of the norm for me. There were some bouts of minor depression, but is was usually in relation to stress at work or family issues, so something that would normally upset me just got to me a little bit more than the norm. And yes, the lack of libado was definately there occasionaly. I decided to remove Mirena after my husband I decided it was time to start our family. Removal was painful but quick, it literally felt like a spasm in my gut with a sharp cramp, but after that I've had no problems. I've started a cycle, probably as a result of removing the BC. Overall this method works well, but you have to know your body and what you can handle. It's great for folks who have a hard time remembering to take the pill, or in my case developed DVTs/clots on the pill. I don't think I'll go back on it, but I would reccomend it to folks who have a busy lifestyle, and dont want to worry about things like this.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had the Mirena IUD put in 6 months ago and had it removed today. It was incredibly painful when they put it in. I felt I was not properly forewarned of that! I had cramps for the next several days. No periods for the first few months but severe cystic acne. Finally found out this is easily treated with Benzoyl Peroxide.Then came month 6 when I started having anxiety, depression and the worst PMS ever. That was enough for me. The removal it out was easy, barely felt it. Feeling nauseous now so I'm hoping that goes away soon.

column2: Jsosa86, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had the mirena put in a few weeks ago, just after I had my third baby. When the doctor was putting it in it felt like I was in labor again. A couple hours later I had the worst cramps ever. So at the time of my 2 week checkup to make sure it was in the right place. It WASNT. I had to go for an ultrasound only to be told that is must have falling out. I do not recommend.

column2: Laci, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I loved having the Mirena IUD. I did not experience any side effects and my periods stopped which was wonderful! When my husband and I chose to have another baby, we got pregnant on our first try!

column2: kim, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: i had the mirena inserted when my daughter was 4 months old, & kept it in for just under 5 yrs. it was removed in 10/2010. my gyno tried to convince me to keep it in longer, but after several conversations with friends in the medical field, i was nervous. the first came about as i was complaining to a friend about all the issues i had been having, & she said, you have the mirena, don't you? & i replied yes, why? & she said those types of complaints are becoming more common with mirena users. so i had it removed. that was pretty painful, my dr said the tissue had started started to grow around it. initially my periods were ok, after not having one for so long, it was easy to handle. but last month my period was 2 wks late. the only other time i've been late was when i was pregnant. there was no chance i could be pregnant. i did some reasearch on the internet, & found a forum where hundreds of women ranging from 19yrs old up age 45, all stating that they were either premenopausal or had already gone through menopause, stating they had all had the mirena, & it was the cause. of course, i started to panic. this month my period was on time, but extremely painful & mostly clots. i will not try the mirena again, & i urge everyone who would like to possibly have children in the future to be extremely cautious. unfortunately, i do not have health ins right now, so i am trying to just wait it out & be hopeful.

column2: Keta, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Mirena has been great for me. Very few periods and light spotting every know and then. I did experience being nauseas the past couple of months. The pass couple of days I have been feeling little flutters in my abdomen. I am feeling like I could be pregnant but from reading other reviews I have seen similiar symptoms except the fluttering. It will be five years in January since i had the mirena inserted. As long as Im not pregnant now I will be making an appt. to get a new one.

column2: RCMomof2, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I decided to get mirena after my second child was born (back in 2008). When the doctor inserted it there was pain and I did bleed just a little bit. After that my period COMPLETELY STOPPED!!! I didn't notice any side effects up till now! I couldn't figure out for the life of me why I was sooo depressed, nervous and anxious right around the time I would normally get my period! I've never had high blood pressure but I do now, never had trouble breathing- I do now, NEVER got headaches I get them all the time, acne is HORRIBLE, I don't ever feel like having sex, and I've had a few panic attacks! There is no other logical explanation for my behavior other then MIRENA! Do you or anyone you know have the same problems?? I feel like I'm going crazy! I haven't seen a doctor yet but after researching the side effects of Mirena all the problems  and side effects that I've had were ALL listed! It's not worth it anymore! But I will note the only good thing about mirena is that it's  been nice not having to worry about taking a pill everyday and not having my period

column2: TBM, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I, too, have read many unsatisfactory reviews on the Mirena birth control method. I am about a year and a half into my second Mirena and I love it! Insertion and removal were both pretty easy for me, felt like cramps. The main thing is to relax while it's being inserted and removed. After my first was inserted, my first period after lasted three weeks...no joke. For the first year, my periods lasted about two weeks, but they eventually got shorter, lighter, and far between. Now, I may spot a couple of times per year and not even enough to wear a pantyliner. When my second Mirena was inserted, I never experienced the three week periods like I did with the first one. I only felt a little like I had morning sickness every once in awhile. My nurse-midwife explained to me that my uteran wall was already thinned, so with the new progestin in the Mirena was going straight into my system and making me feel that way. Since then, I feel fine...just have achy breasts every once in awhile. I never feel it, however, my boyfriend does complain on occasion that he can feel the strings and they sometimes hurt him during intercourse. When that happens we either change positions or I've learned that I can tuck the strings around the side of my cervix. My Mirena really is the best thing I have ever used for birth control. I have never had a pregnancy scare on it, or ever worried that I may become pregnant, I was told that as long as I can feel the strings, it's working. My nurse-midwife told me that she hasn't seen any failures on it and she has been practicing for as long as it's been around.

column2: Crystal, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have read so many horror stories on the mirena so I thought I would share my experience to help those who are thinking about trying it. I've only had my mirena for 6 days so far but I am very happy with it so far. Insertion was not painful at all, a little cramping but if you've had children it's nothing compared to child birth. Spotted for 2 days afterwards. Also had a headache the first 3 days but now I could be happier. It is perfect for me since I've had bad problems with every other bc I've tried.

column2: RaiderFan, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had Mirena put in about a week ago. It was uncomfortale at most but only lasted a few hours. By the next day I could not even feel it. I only bled for two days. After having our son my Husband and I have decided we are not quite ready for another child and having this gives us a great peace of mind.  Sex was not uncomfortable at all. We could not tell a difference. So far I would recommend having this inserted.

column2: lauren, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Mirena has been a mixed bag for me. I have had it for 18 months, and it is perfect at preventing pregnancy. However, the side effects have been so bad that I've scheduled an appointment to have it removed. I have terrible mood swings that have almost destroyed my marraige, very decreased sex drive, minor weight gain,  and cystic acne. On the upside, I no longer have periods and I don't have any cramping or discomfort. I'll have to find something else that works without turning me into a monster.

column2: Txgal, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I had a Paraguard IUD but switched because I had heavy periods (pre-dating Paraguard). Everything had seemed to be fine. I've been having trouble losing weight and just blamed it on other life changes. I finally recognized the correlation of symptoms to the Mirena. The posts even support my hair loss being attributable. I am scheduled to have it removed in a couple of weeks. I noticed another review saying she felt like being pregnant. YES! I have felt that way, too. My stomach is even rounded and I somewhat waddle, just like when I was pregnant 5 years ago.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Insertion was agonising, but subsided after about an hour. Bled for 6wks on & off. 3mnths later I'm ecstatic not to have extended bleeding. Only downside is bleeding after intercourse, no pain though. Lasts for a few hours so makes me self conscious.

column2: Would not recommend , 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I opted for this after my third child - insertion was more painful than 16 hours of pitocin contractions with no epidural! I begged them to stop after their third attempt but they got it in on the fourth. Bled for the next month and a half. After that it was okay in the period department - random spotting and cramping but that was it. As time went on though bleeding after intercourse got worse, sex drive was declining and couldn't lose weight to save my life so chose to have it removed after a year and a half. No pain at all on removal and nurse midwife was surprised I'd had it in as long as I had - she's had a lot of complaints about it. I would not recommend this product.

column2: REDLADYJ, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had the Mirena for almost 5yrs and in the process of getting it removed next month and contemplating tubular ligation on insertion of a new one. During insertion it was uncomfortable but tolerable.  Since I have had it I didn't experience much discomfort up until last year.  Generally, I am in pain during and after intercourse and bleed as if I am on my cycle. My cycles have always been light in the past but were unpredictable so I always wear pantiliners as a precaution.  I do cramp now more often, have gas and bloating, headaches and get my cycle several times a month which lasts most times 7-14 days but are very light.  I do have an occassional heavy cycle.  Also, I can feel pressure in my pelvic area at times and pain.  I have gained 30lbs over the last 5yrs and have been having a hard time losing it, I am always fatigued and sluggish. I have had several bacterial infections and attribute it to the mirena since I never had them in the past. I am losing hair but fortunately its not noticeable at this point. I am not trying to say that mirena is not a good product but I am having more issues now than in the past.

column2: Ruby, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I got mirena put in 3 years ago. The insertion was painful but tolerable. I bled very little and had little cramping. After about 6 months i stopped having periods completely. I loved not having periods! However, after the first year i started gaining weight and i was a very active person always exercising. Then i started having 2 to 3 periods a month!! me no likey!! So I went to my gyno she said everything was fine, the mirena was in place and she put me on birth control pills to straighten out my periods. I also started having TERRIBLE pelvic pain that sent me to the er several times. Turned out the pain was caused by ovarian cysts. I get them consistently since having the mirena. Also sex sometimes hurts and I bleed after. My boyfriend gets poked by the strings and he hates it. So since the mirena i've been gaining weight, can't sleep, very fatigue, pelvic pain, body aches, muscle weakness, hair loss,and headaches. But the doctors still tell me it's not the birth control. But after reading these reviews how could it not be!

column2: NurseBailey, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I'm a nurse, and I've had the Mirena for right at 3 years, and the first 2 1/2 years were great! Very few periods, the ones I did have were 3 days or less. But the last 6 months have been AWFUL. Pelvic pain, mostly on my right side in the area of my right ovary often feeling like heavy cramping and muscle spasm, painful intercourse that has caused bleeding, and now my periods are lasting 2 or more weeks!! I went to have the device checked by my family doctor, and part of the device has fused to my uterine wall...so now I have to have it removed, possibly surgically in three weeks. Also, I have four other friends my age with this same device, and we've all experienced continual hair loss throughout the time we've had these devices. I'm the last one of my girlfriends to get mine removed. I believe the Mirena does it's job, because I have not gotten pregnant within the last three years. My husband only complains occasionally of being able to feel it during intercourse. BUT...I think it should be taken out after the first two to three years. Most of the reviews I have read and people I've talked with, and in my own experience as well, this device is great for that period of time. It seems the side effects begin to show up fairly quickly after that time. Hope this helps!!

column2: angelsoul8908, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: My daughter was born August 19, 2009. I had mirena inserted April of 2010. It was painful, but nothing compared to giving birth. It does its job as I've not gotten pregnant to my knowledge and my periods have been shorter and more spread out. The things I do not like is a very long list I regret to say. First off, Sex at some angles hurt alot not to mention my husband has been scratched many times. My sex drive does not seem has high as it was pre-mirena, which sucks because what's the use of having an IUD, if you don't feel like having sex as much? Once a month or so, I feel as if I am pregnant, I've been having cravings, butterflies, pain, bloating, fatigue, and weight gain. I know those are some of the side effects of mirena, but should I really be feeling something moving on the inside? At times I'm certain I'm pregnant but when I go to the docter, the urine test comes back negative. I've been so tired lately at at times it's hard keeping up with my 2 year old. Has anyone else felt like they were pregnant? I know the exact feeling seeing as I've already been down that road. lol. If I were giving a second shot, I would have used something other then Mirena. The side effects are just too much. Though I'm constantly fighting with myself if it's bad enough to worry about the hassle of getting it removed. Has anyone had similiar problems?

column2: Meli, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I recently got mirena inserted on 7/27/11. I have to say I was pretty scared to get it done, reading all these bad reviews but I still decided to give it a try. Getting it inserted did not hurt at all,took about 5 mins, had no cramping just a little bleeding which stopped in couple hours. I forget I even have it in.  I haven't had any problems. So far I'm happy with Mirena.

column2: tamprtch, 45-54 Female  (Patient)
column9: I went today to have the Mirena inserted.  I took 800mg of ibuprofen 1 hour prior as recommended. The doctor began the process, the cramping and pain was tremendous for me.  He said he didnt think I would  do well with the Mirena even if he could finish the insertion because he thought it would cause me severe cramping every month with the pain I was having just with insertion.  So he stopped and I didnt get it.  It has been 7 hours and I am still cramping and bleeding just from him clamping the cervix and beginning the dilation of the cervix for measurements of the uturus.  I don't know how anyone can do it without being knocked out first.  I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia years ago which does  cause overactive nerve  sensors and the pain threshold to be less.

column2: Queenqbh, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had my Mirena inserted 6/16/2011 six weeks after having my first child, Implanting the Mirena was painless compared to natural child birth lol. My boyfriend has no problems with the threads and he has a very large package. My fingers are to short to reach my threads so my boyfriend checks for the threads periodically. Mireana may be the best birth controll i have ever tryed. I havent experienced any of the horrible side effects mentioned on this site.I love my mirena so far, if anything changes i will be sure to write a review.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I got the mirena 7 wks after giving birth and had it for 7months. I had it removed because of the drastic changes that accured around the 6month. I had bad cramping, horrible mood swings that seemed like never ending PMS, i started gaining weight and this all made me feel so depressed and my husband was really having a hard time understanding why i was so bitchy all the time! I let this go on for about a month before i put it all together and made the appt. to have it removed. I immediately felt better the next day. My sister has had it now for 2yrs and has had many of the same issues but the dr. talked her out of removing it and is trying an antideppresent to help with the mood swings but she also has had the weight gain and cant seem to work it off. i know everyone is different but just keep all the side effects in mind before getting one for yourself.

column2: chel-c_paige, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had mirena inserted Feb '09. I started having bad migraines, nausea, dizziness, vomiting, decreased sex drive, mood swings in dec '10 Went to the doctor in feb '11 discussing my symptoms and they gave me some pain meds and nausea meds. Which helped for a little bit the meds made me feel wierd like i was on autopilot. So i went back again, gave me different meds, which i couldnt take upset stomach along with my regular symptoms then i kept having this pain, and hardness in my lower left abdomen, painful sex, doctor said my cervix and uterus were swollen, cramping, just horrible pain and very annoying. went to the doctor again she told me i had a pelvic infection due to mirena and if i keep getting them it will decrease the chance of conceiving later on in life. (i want more kids :)) I take 2 different meds 4 times a day for 10 days  i see a little improvement, which didnt last long. I had the worst migraine ive ever had in my life and vomiting so i go to the hospital, waited for 5 and a half hours finally got seen by a doctor, he gave me and inflammation shot and a pain killer for head. i was feeling great, the next day the inflammation hadnt wore of yet, had no pain it was amazing... even though i had slept allll day long, the next day the paion had returned, I decided to go to the doctor and demand they take this stupid thing out which they did, had slight spotting little cramping, that day i started the nuvaring, which is effective, but i am still having painful sex, pelvic pain, nausea, dizziness, vomiting, mood swings. If anyone else has had any of these symptoms, or a relief for this please let me know. Thanks

column2: kat, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Caregiver)
column9: I got the Mirena put in about 6 months ago, 7 weeks after having my baby. the insertion didnt hurt, i actually didnt fel it at all. it took about 10 min tops to insert. i do recommend taking some sort of motron before appointment to ease the pain. after insertion i had a 32 day period, wasnt really expecting that. but after that was finally done i rarely have a period. its not monthly and when i do have a period its light, not even enought to put a tampon in. although intercourse has been at times a little painful, but not too bad (not enough to want to remove it) the mirena overall has been awesome! i have never been able to take any other kind of birth control. it always made me sick, too much hormones in it i guess. and i could never remember to take it. so this is great for those of you who cant remember. and my partner has never complained about being able to feel it.

column2: amyS29, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had it put in 3yrs ago. It is reliable & you don't have to worry about forgeting itbut it has caused painful intercourse, my husband can feel it & sometimes scratches him, I have had a hard time controlling my weight & that was never an issue before & caused my skin to breakout which wasn't an issue before either. I'm actually getting it taken out next week.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: period everyday pain in pelvic depression

column2: Sugarplum77, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had the mirena fitted in April after being told that it was great,I have 4 children and am not planning any more so this was a perfect solution,I had it fitted whilst having a biopsy on my womb so I felt no pain and recovered quickly.I didn't think I had any issues until I started loosing hair.At first I didn't make ant connection,but found it hard to figure why I had never suffered alopecia before,after researching I found that one of the side effects of the coil is alopecia but it is not noted on the information booklet as only 1 in 20 women suffer,I have now got 3 huge bald patches and half an eyebrow missing,all in the space of 3 months,to say I am shocked is an understatement,I have also been for my first check to find that the strings are missing so now I am awaiting a scan to find it before I can ask for it to be removed!,I have never felt so let down by a contraceptive and can't wait to get rid of it,I'm glad it works for a lot of women but for me it has failed miserably,I'm not likely to get pregnant because I feel so ugly,not because of the coil it's self!...just please be aware of ALL the side effects,I wasn't when I had it put in.......I wish I had been.

column2: ashleydawn0304, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had the mirena in for 2 years now and it has been great for me, up until about 2 months ago. Now I have pain in my pelvic area often, and swelling. Ive had to go to the hospital for the pain and ive seen my gyno, but both say everything is fine. Hopefully itll work itself out because my doctors arent doing anything and arent concerned. I really wouldnt recommend getting this form of birth control if you arent ready for the pain that comes with it.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had the Mirena for 3 years now. Heavier menstral cycles and painful intercourse for me from day one. I feel so miserable with this birth control method. I've had pain so severe that Ive had to go to the hospital.

column2: MeeCee, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have had Mirena for about a year and a half. Before getting it I would recommend you learn all that is involved with it. The day of implantation, you should take the strongest pain med your doctor approves. I had what felt like contractons the first day and some discomfort the next two days. I also experienced mood swings in the months following my procedure. The only complaint I have is that I never seem to stop spotting. I have to wear a pad everyday. There are even days when I think I'm having a period. It's affecting my sex life with my husband. I am thinking of having the Mirena removed and returning to Depo.

column2: Emily, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: I had the Mirena inserted 6 months after having my first child.  As for the insertion experience, I didn't experience any pain.  (Then again, I had it inserted post-baby, so my pain threshold has increased dramatically.)  That being said, I did experience a slight visceral reaction (which if you've never had it, can only be compared to a wave of nausea), but it dissipated after a few minutes.  I experienced intermittent cramping for 2-3 days, but nothing that required OTC medication.  I spotting for about 3-months afterwards, so I wore a pantyliner almost always, even though it was barely enough blood to change it more than once or twice a day.  After 3 months, I began experiencing intermittent periods that lasted about 3-5 days, but they were much lighter than before AND I experienced no bloating, cramping, breakouts, etc.,  that have always been associated with my cycles.  Eventually, the period is supposed to cease all together, for which I am incredibly thankful.  (Especially because they are associating higher rates of reproductive cancers with woman who menstruate regularly for decades with no interruption.)  Regarding sex: My partner has never been able to feel them and they have caused me no discomfort.  Overall, the Mirena has been an extremely positive experience.  I usually forget that I even have it.

column2: Charis, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Im 26, have had Mirena for four years, and I love it. Yes, insertion was painful. I think the doctor who did my insertion was not very experienced with IUDs because she cut the strings too short. You're supposed to check that it's in place after every period but I can't feel the strings; however my doctor checks it every year with ultrasound and says it's fine, it's in the right place. Over time, Mirena changed my periods from a moderate flow to light spotting. I haven't needed to use a tampon in years. My overall experience with Mirena has been a breeze. I haven't had any of the nightmare side effects that some of the other reviewers experienced. I recommend at least trying Mirena if you're looking for an easy, highly effective birth control method, and are in a monogamous relationship (or are very good about using condoms every time). Research it and see if it fits with your lifestyle. For me, getting Mirena was the best possible decision to make. My boyfriend (now husband) and I knew I needed to finish graduate school and get a job before even thinking of having kids. I never want to be in a situation where I'd have to choose between ending a pregnancy or having a baby before I'm emotionally and financially ready for it. Mirena has made birth control a no brainer for me.

column2: maxsmomma1, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: The insertion wasn't pleasant but it wasn't as bad as labor. I have had three periods since I got it put in 6 months ago. The first one lasted 6 weeks but it was light spotting. Since then each has just mostly been light spotting and lasted less than a week. I hardly cramp now and my face is clear! I love not having to worry about taking a pill every day or getting pregnant. It's carefree birth control! love it!

column2: Tam, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I first had the Paraguard inserted in 2008 and had it removed just 6 short months after, due to heavy, clotty, painful periods. I went along with my dr's suggestion to try Mirena, and I am scheduled to have it removed in two weeks. Over the last 3 yrs, i have and still currently experience fatigue, cycles that 1) last for two weeks and heavy, 2)random, or 3)spot for weeks on end. Even after having the strings trimmed, my significant other still feels them. I have had at LEAST 3 yeast infections this year alone, odor, and brown yucky discharge. I never had a problem with acne, but this has my face looking like connect the dots. All my personal experience...need I say more??

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had the device put in on May 5, 2011. It was a painful insertion but bearable. My experience with the Mirena has been hell. I went from a 3 day period pre-merina to bleeding everyday for 2 1/2 months. (flowing like a water fountain) I currently still have the device in and am taking birth control pills as well to slow down the bleeding. I researched and spoke with others prior to getting it and heard nothing but good reviews....my body just seems to wanna reject it. I plan to have it removed really soon.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I got Mirena about 3 weeks ago. Insertion was extremely painful, and i cramped only pretty bad for 2 days, but then only slight cramps. I didn't even spot. But then I tried to have sex. I was unaware that the "strings" that hang down into your vagina are long metal coils. My boyfriend can feel them during sex and they are extremely sharp and painful.My doctor supposedly trimmed them all the way back, but we could both still feel them.I had my Mirena removed after having it in for 3 weeks. I immediately felt a mood change and saw more acne. I had slight cramps the entire 3 weeks and towards the end was cramping during sex.  I knew deep down that Mirena was not right for me but felt I had no other choices. The pill had given me high blood pressure so I needed to take something without estrogen. I can see how Mirena would work for some people, however I think it really depends on how you and your partner are shaped. My boyfriend is a little on the larger side and also uncircumcised, which I think has something to do with it. There is no way that something like Mirena could work for everyone. I would also appreciate if the Mirena pamphlet was more upfront about what kind of "micro-filaments" they are using because it's not really clear that it is a metal coil. When I went to have Mirena removed the doctor lectured me and tried to guilt trip me into keeping it. So i'd say really think about all of the consequences and what is right for you and your partner. It's one thing to start and stop a pill or a patch but it's a completely other story having something implanted into your body that hurts your boyfriend, and not being able to remove it. That was the worst feeling.

column2: oscardagrouch, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Im 45 and went on the mirena when I was 41. I think it is great for birth control - but I am beginning to wonder about the side effects. I also have to consider that I moved countries and went into a new career all around the same time as beginning to use the IUD. I have been suffering with depression pretty much since arriving in Australia.  This also happens to be about the ame amount of time I have been using a mirena. - I have highs and lows. The other thing is in the last 2 years I have put on alot of weight and have no motivation to exercise anymore, and I use to be very active and currently I do a very physical job.  I will be replacing it soon but will discuss more my experience with the doctor and perhaps there will be better options than just the mirena for me. I am not ready to 'neuter' myself by getting my tubes tied. But I dont want to have any more kids. Really what WE WANT is a contraceptive that has NO side effects except that it gives me heaps of energy and  makes me feel FANTASTIC!!! - anyone working on that at the moment???

I would recommend it in a heartbeat. I have had it for 2 yrs now. Insertion was hardly painfull, it felt like a pinch at the most and no weight gain. I was told that it would decrease period flow at the very least, if not eliminate it totally. That's exactly what has happened. I've maybe had 2 periods since and they were extremely light, never lasting more than half a day.  I find it hard to believe that it can be felt during intercourse since it's in your uterus. I hope this helps your decision.

column2: scared , 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I decided to post a review because after reading several, the only reviews I found are of recent users. I had mine put in 3 years ago. It was painful during insertion,  but tolerable. For most of the time I have used mirena, I have been satisfied, although my spouse can feel it during penetration. I am currently experiencing severe pain after sex, for the second time. I regret getting it and plan to have it removed immediately. The pain is bad enough to call 911!

column2: kathryn, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had the Mirena inserted in March 2011. Insertion totally painless and troublefree. I spotted for 2 months, then had hardly any period. HOWEVER after 3 months, I detected a large, hard , thick area in my breast. Was NOT there previously. Went through some scary biopsies and it was benign, however, I realized that if you read the Physician Insert (rather than the Patient Insert- they are different!) that Breast Cancer is listed as a possible side effect. My psychiatrist also strongly recommended getting it removed. So I am next week. I'd rather have a hysterectomy than live with those risks.

column2: mstxnkc, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years
column9: I had my IUD inserted six weeks after my second child in 2007. I chose to use Mirena after extensive research and found it to be the best one for my situation. I have not experienced any unusual pain since having it inserted. My periods became lighter and lighter over the course of three months until they stopped all-together. My husband cannot feel it during intercourse. I will be taking it out next summer and will use Mirena in the future for birth control.

column2: dogluvr, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: After reading a LOT of horror stories, I decided most people only write negative things. I decided to try Mirena. I've been on Hormonal Birth control for 12 years straight. I'm 28 no children or pregnancies. But, I smoke and my Doctor wanted me off all the hormones. It was painful to get inserted, I cramped for a day, and now I'm fine. I've had no pain, no spotting (though I've been on birthcontrol so long it could be my lining is thinner which stops bleeding. I haven't had a period in 3 years anyway). But my husband and I can't feel it, I go for my check up in 2 months, but so far so good. Oh and I lost about 3# the first week. :) Just try it ladies, if it doesn't work for you, take it out. But, if you've been on the pill for a long time like me, remember some of the side effects are from your body being OFF hormones for the first time..... I would reccomend this to other women as a form of worry/hassle free birth control

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: After reading some of the comments, I find it necessary to write about my Mirena...I have it in for about 3 years & I pretty much debate daily whether or not to take it out. Fortunately, I haven't had any acne problems or yo-yo weight issues, but have been plagued with occasional but painful cramps. Before getting the Mirena I never had a yeast infection, now I average about 2-3 a year. And sex hurts...which is a freaking bummer. I don't doubt it's effectiveness, I'm in my 30's & super fertile (pregnant twice, once on NuvaRing & the other on the pill within a couple of months) so my options were pretty limited - my doc recommended & I agreed. However, now that I know what I know I probably would have never had it put in me. The other thing that annoys me(I've noticed this being mentioned often) is that my doctor as well turned the whole conversation around, asking me what I was doing differently & that in no way possible was the Mirena causing any of these symptoms. I think at one point she said that it's still early, but it's been 3 years now, and I'm sure the little thing is causing my discomfort.

column2: Unsatisfied,  Female  (Patient)
column9: This is the WORST piece of garbage ever invented.  I would not wait until worse side effects occur, get it removed immediately.  Don't let the doctor talk you into keeping it, I was miserable for six weeks.  Side effects i had included, bleeding, painful intercourse, hair loss, insomnia, and hives.  (Also it was uncomfortable when i sit down.)I really don't know why doctors push for you to keep it, remember its your body.

column2: No Regrets, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had my Mirena IU placed approximately 12 weeks after the birth of my 1st child.  I have had no regrets.  Placement was no more painful than a Pap Smear and while I did experience some mild cramping post placement a single dose of Advil solved that.  I never had any spotting or bleeding.  I have not had a "period" since Nov 2007 (the month prior to conception of our son) -- I expected this since I was breastfeeding at the time of placement but did take pregnancy tests monthly for the 1st year just in case.  The Mirena had no adverse affects on my breastfeeding or milk supply.  I have not experienced any additional weight gain and have actually return to my pre-pregnancy weight.  I will be having the Mirena removed next week as we try to conceive our next child -- but I will definitely consider using the Mirena again.

column2: LadyDee27, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had My Mirena inserted 6/13/11. I was nervous getting it put in but my doctor talked me through the process which felt alot like menstrual cramps. Afterwards I got dressed and took Tylenol to ease my pain. As soon as I was about to leave I started feeling weak like I couldnt walk I felt nauseous and my pain was concentrated on my left side and I couldnt sit up straight. I ended up being in the clinic waiting room for about 45 mins waiting for my meds to kick in contemplating on having it removed right away. Thankfully pain subsided and for the first few days i had mild cramping and very light bleeding. After a week and a half I started breaking out on my face shoulders back and chest(bumps the size of a head on a straight pin) nothing horrible. I noticed I'm alot more tired now and I'm basically bleeding all day every day and the cramps are worse than before(I had a heavy flow before Mirena) and the clots that I'm passing are just ridiculously huge compared to before. The sex hasnt been affected...hopefully it stays that way but its very annoying bleeding all day and half the night and cramping all the time. I'm really trying to hold out and see if it gets better as time goes on and I'm hoping I get to be as lucky as a few ladies who stopped getting their periods.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I had the mirena put in April of 2010 for heavy and painful periods. That was the worst decision of my life!! The insertion was HORRIBLLY PAINFUL! The worst pain I've ever felt. I was in pain for weeks before I felt the tiniest bit of relief. The cramps and back pain was unbearable.I couldnt even sit down! On top of that, my bowels were a mess! I have IBS and it was all out of wack - severly constipated and pains in my stomach. It then switched to severe diarrhea. It got so bad I had to see a GI specialist. I felt like I was having constant problems and constant pain.I was still cramping and bleeding 6 mo later. I had the placement checked and cultures done to rule out infections. I also gained 8 lbs instantly and it was impossible to get rid it. I couldnt exercise w/o having terrible cramps. I also had constant headaches, lasting for a month at a time. After 1 year, my period had regulated somewhat. I could not use tampons as they were uncomfortable and had to deal with pads. The cramps were still bad - 2 weeks out of the month. My sex drive was completely gone and if I did have sex, I usually bled afterwards, cramped or was uncomfortable. I finally found a doctor who would help. She did an exam and found a large cyst on my ovary. I had to have several ultrasounds to monitor the size. The cyst continued to grow and not break down so my doc said it was time for the IUD to come out since cysts are a side effect. I had it removed 3 weeks ago - it was completly painless!! I barely felt anything! It was an immediate sense of relief! I was put on the pill to help break down the cyst. I have already lost most of the weight. My stomach feel great, my moods are better, my sex drive is coming back,I have energy again, I'm not in any pain and I don't feel like I'm going crazy anymore! So far getting the mirena removed was the best thing I could have done! I def. regret ever having it! The pain and side effects are NOT worth it at all! I WOULD NOT RECCOMMEND THIS TO ANYONE

column2: Fruckstratd, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have one child and instead of trying birth control pills or the depo shot, I decided to get the Mirena BIG MISTAKE!! My pelvic area has pains that I've never felt before! I have longer periods it seems that it won't ever stop, I hate it n my bf does too we can't ever have sex like we used to because as soon as my stomach cramps(3-4 times a week) I bleed sometimes it stops other times I bleed for weeks straight. I am having mine removed before I go crazy!

column2: FeFe29, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had it placed in march 2011, It was not painfull like others had explained. Not even a pinch! A couple of hrs i did expierance some mild to moderate cramping for just the night and it was gone. My periods were always super heavy and that is a thing of the past! I spoted for a couple of days for the first 2 months then it stoped. sooo nice : ) I havent had any of the scary side effects like some women have reported. I did have maybe a hand full of random cramps but it has stoped (3 months) My husband nor i can feel the "threads" I think the girls who had pain while insertion had it done WRONG. you shouldnt feel really anything! my dr filded the "threads over so you can feel them but they don't "poke" your partner. Overall i am very satisfyed with the mirena so far. I do have some breast tenderness,(little) which is normal for hormonal birth controll users. I had some moderate bloating b4 it would of been my period. then went away. I recomend it to girls who have had a child because your uterus is been subjected to objects being inside. To the women who had problems with it, you are prolly sensitive to the hormane AND the dr, who put it in didn't do it right!!! I do recomend you take the day off of work or other activites the day you have it inserted, so you can ajust to the IUD. I would deffinatly get another if it continues to be great like this : )

column2: trieditall, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had tried several birth control methods and they all made sick (vomiting, nausea, dizziness) After having my first child I decided to try the mirena since nothing else worked. column2: Xx_lc_xX, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm 24 and I chose this type of birth control b/c I'm horrible at taking the pill and horrible at using even the Nuva-ring. Also, I am temporarily living abroad and this is the easiest and most effective choice for me. I read a ton of reviews before deciding to go this route. So far, after a little over 5 months, I am really happy I chose Mirena.The insertion took about 15 minutes and was a little awkward and hurt a bit because of the cramping but not unbearable. I took some Tylenol before going to the appointment like my doc told me, drove there, had the insertion, bled a tiny bit into the panty liner they gave me, drove to a holiday work dinner with a bit of discomfort but survived. It took about a month for the cramping and uneasiness to go away but now, I don't even realize it's there.A bad thing about this is that my skin has been breaking out by no longer taking the pill and being in a different environment. That's a downside but the best part about Mirena is no more periods! Each month, I may have a little brown discharge but don't need panty liner or tampons or anything.I plan to keep Mirena in for the whole 5 years and hopefully afterwards, I won't have any problems getting pregnant if I want. I heard some rumors that you shouldn't choose an IUD if you haven't ever been pregnant but I guess I will find out if that's true in 4.5 years. Wish me luck.

column2: Char, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I know some people have no trouble with Mirena, but for me it's been not at all worth the problems! I've had morning sickness and other pregnancy symtpoms for the 2 years I had it. After a few short months it got lost in my uterus, but I didn't have insurance for removal. I worried all the time about it, until last week when it was removed. The procedure was the WORST pain ever, worse than 3 childbirths, worse than a bad kidney stone! Now, a few days later, I have an infection from the procedure, which involved a night of teriible pain, vomiting, diarrhea and such a high fever I was delusional. I thought this would be the easiest birth control with no side effects, but this ordeal is not worth it! I wish I could put up signs everywhere telling women to never risk it -- you may not have these problems, but it's just not worth the risk in my opinion. If I'd known of these possibilities, I never, ever would have chosen it. It's easier to have a baby than go through that removal and infection!

column2: fiona, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
Amy , 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been on Mirena for 8 months and have recently decided to have it removed. I have experienced a myriad of uncomfortable daily symptoms that I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy including: extreme lower back pain, daily spotting/light flow for the first 4 months and sporadic spotting since, nausea during my "period," weight gain, sporadic acne, weird discharge, depression, and decrease in libido. It also changed the taste of my breast milk causing my infant to reject the breast. My milk supply simply dried up exactly 2 weeks after insertion even with the help of drugs and supplements to boost my supply. My doctor basically told me to "tough it out" because the symptoms/side effects subside after 6 months, and that there was no evidence that it effected breast milk supply (I don't care what the drug company says, it does). I am on month 8, and the symptoms have not subsided. I have NEVER had any side effects with any other type of birth control I have tried in the past. I would encourage women to do some serious research prior to having this device inserted. I felt I was talked into it by my Dr. and insurance company (who paid 100% on Mirena, but will not pay a significant amount on regular birth control pills)due to cost effectiveness and trendiness. I really feel like having the device inserted was one of my worst decisions, and I am just praying that I do not have any permanent issues due to my decision.

column2: brandie, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

The iud has a little pinching feeling for like two seconds which you can ask for local anestesia, i didnt though. compared to painful messy smelly periods and having to remember pills,which screws up your relationships because you cant even relax thinking you might get pregnant when not ready, mirena iud is awsome. Which i am now finally being treated for because i jump in myn sleep and cause myself to get out of my sleep patterns, we dont know if its associated with the hormone from the mirens(levonorgestrel) ,i believe its called.n its a low dose, oh forgot to mention, the hormon is centralized for the reproductive part of our body unlike a pill that goes through our blood system first. This is centralized for your ovaries,uterus. Hope it works out for you, as much as it did for me and my family, good luck to all !!

column2: maryjane, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I wanted to write a review because I was absolutely petrified to get mirena after reading some of the stories on the web.  I have always had painful periods so honestly, the insertion wasn't nearly as bad as I thought it would be.  yes it hurt, but only for a moment and it was nothing worse than what i go through on a monthly basis.  I've only had mirena for a little over a month now and i have been spotting a lot but i'm going to give it another two months because not worrying about having to take birthcontrol everyday is worth it.  The cramps come and go but again, I suffered horrible period pain for years so it is bearable.  i got nervous i would gain a ton of weight but so far so good.  I've kept eating right and going to the gym and doing yoga regularly.  every woman is different so of course we will all react differently.

I loved the Mirena, had it inserted shortly after the birth of my first child.  I can't recall any related side effects, and while the insertion was mildly painful, I was fine by the next day.  I lost all the baby weight and an additional 10 lbs, so it did not cause weight gain.  Unfortunately, my husband had problems with it because he would feel it poking during intercourse.  I'm surprised no one else has mentioned that.  The GYN shortened the wires, but they were still bothering him, which obviously hampered our sex life!  After 6 months I had it removed and was pregnant 6 weeks later!  Now after my second child I'm using depo, and the side effects seem much worse than Mirena had been.  I'd recommend it to anyone, and wish I could go back on it!
